title: autotelic
text:
A site dedicated to my programming and statistics learning journey where I’ll record what I read, summarize, explain and learn from a wide variety of topics all related to programming, statistics, and occasionally, some other subjects.
The goal is that, within a 12-month period, I’ll be able to learn from three good, solid books and use this new found knowledge in my day–to–day life to create and improve something, however small it is. At the end of the year, I should see the tangible fruit of my labors, either virtually on the “interweb” or in physical form.

title: Chapters 1–4
text:
Codelibrary(polycor)

# Let's create some made-up factor variables, Quality of Product 
# and Performance of the product on a scale from 1 - 5 and 1 - 4. 

df <- data.frame(Qual = factor(rep(1:5,each = 20), 
                          labels = c("Strongly Agree", 
                                     "Agree",
                                     "Neutral", 
                                     "Disagree", 
                                    "Strongly Disagree")),
                 Perform = factor(rep(1:4, each = 25), 
                             labels = c("Very Low",
                                        "Low",
                                        "Medium",
                                        "High")))

# Now let's calculate the correlation between these two variables

poly_cor <- polycor::polychor(df$Qual, df$Perform, ML = FALSE)

# [1] .993 This is the correlation estimate for our data. 
# Performance and Quality are strongly correlated.

title: Chapters 1–4
text:
Codelibrary(polycor)

# Let's create some made-up factor variables, Quality of Product 
# and Performance of the product on a scale from 1 - 5 and 1 - 4. 

df <- data.frame(Qual = factor(rep(1:5,each = 20), 
                          labels = c("Strongly Agree", 
                                     "Agree",
                                     "Neutral", 
                                     "Disagree", 
                                    "Strongly Disagree")),
                 Perform = factor(rep(1:4, each = 25), 
                             labels = c("Very Low",
                                        "Low",
                                        "Medium",
                                        "High")))

# Now let's calculate the correlation between these two variables

poly_cor <- polycor::polychor(df$Qual, df$Perform, ML = FALSE)

# [1] .993 This is the correlation estimate for our data. 
# Performance and Quality are strongly correlated.
